app.note: I believe a spiral may be present here, but I am not sure. PS's edition has a note anchor with the number 2 after the initial word svasti, but note 2 of his paper is certainly not meant to go here. I think he must have intended to re-attach note 16 here. His original note 16 is attached likewise after the opening svasti in the first charter edited in his article, and mentions a spiral symbol at the beginning of the line.
The intent may have been vijayavāṭa-; compare vijayavāṭi-skandhāvārāT in the first set of Peddāpurappāḍu plates.
Since PS does not emend cc, I assume that this is a typo and the plate reads cch.
If this is not a typo in PS, then it may well be a scribal mistake for gātrāṇāṁ, used in the Peṇukapaṟu grant of Jayasiṁha I instead of the standard -vapuṣāṁ.
Compare the Guḍivāḍa plates (set 2) of Jayasiṁha I (line 10) and the Puloṁbūra grant of Jayasiṁha I (line 9).
See the commentary for my reasoning.

There is probably a misreading and/or scribal error here. PS in his discussion describes the teacher as a follower of Aupanīya and vr̥kṣa mūla saṁgha, and ignores the unintelligible /pontikalya/. However, according to the Peddāpurappāḍu plates (set 1) of Viṣṇuvardhana II, Kanakanandi was a member of the the Vr̥kṣamūla Yāpanīya gaṇa, and the name Yāpanīya is also attested in other Eastern Cālukya grants. I am also unable to interpret pontikal (is this a Tamil toponym?), but believe that yāpanīya must have been inscribed, or at least intended here.

Either the scribe or PS's typesetter probably omitted cāryyasya after this word. The number of characters in this line is approximately the same as in the neighbouring lines, so scribal omission seems more likely.
Could this stretch read something like kramuka-sahasra-vr̥kṣa-prarohaṇa or -sthāna?

I wonder if the correct reading may in fact be paścime kasimi, mentioned in line 12 as kisimi but called Kasimi and Kāsimī in PS's discussion (and identified by him as modern Kasimkoṭa in Pithapuram tāluk, East Godavari District).

According to the ARIE report, land was donated to the Bhaṭṭāramañci-vihāra. This implies that the dative ending was correctly read by PS, but nonetheless this vihāra seems to have been listed as a boundary. The following characters very probably include (or were meant to include) āghāṭana, but I do not have a plausible correction for the string as a whole.

This is probably the reading of the plate, and certainly the composer's intent. PS's edition prints literally,
puṇya=āyur=ārogya yaś=bhivr̥ddhaye .

div.head: Plates
div.p:
Greetings from the majestic encampment of victory. Or perhaps, “the encampment at Vijayavāṭa.” See the apparatus to line 1. The grandson of His Majesty King
mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana, who attained victory through daring in many a battle and who was eager to adorn the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra, who are sons of Hārītī, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who have conquered the complete circle of the earth by means of the mere sight of the Boar emblem they have acquired by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose lineage
gotra
Or, “whose limbs;” see the apparatus to line 3. has been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions
avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice—; the dear son of the majestic King mahārāja Indra Bhaṭṭāraka, His Majesty King
mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana II, who was deliberately appointed as heir by his mother and father and whose ever-increasing valour forces the entire circle of subordinate rulers
sāmanta to bow, who achieves prosperity by
means in accordance with the textbooks of moral duty dharmaśāstra composed by Manu and so on, who is true to his word like Yudhiṣṭhira, as versed in polity
naya as Br̥haspati and as versed in discipline

of the people in Mudinī village, who Maṅgirāja had received instruction from Kanakanandi Ācārya who was a disciple of Gihanandi Ācārya who inhabited Purucaināḍu village in Draviḷa territory

viṣaya as follows: Both the reading and the interpretation of the text is problematic at the end of this passage, and my interpretation of it differs from that of the original editor. See the apparatus to lines 9 to 13 on the textual problems, and the commentary for my reasoning.

Let it be known to you that in the course of the second year of the victorious reign, in the course of the month Jyeṣṭha, in the bright fortnight, on the thirteenth, a Monday, PS in his discussion of the grants translates candra-dine as Wednesday. in order to augment our merit, vitality, health and glory, a gift is to be made, I am uncertain of the meaning of the word gokaraṇīyā, but if the reading is correct, it may have been intended to mean that the land in question is to be treated as an “offering” or “property” to be transferred to the Jain master mentioned above. with a remission of all taxes, of two nivartanas of the field of Kavi Alambu and, to the east of that field, also the Toṭa field constituting an orchard of a thousand betelnut trees. The markers of its borders are as follows. To the east and south, the Vihajara-kūṭa field. To the west, the single border
Or perhaps, “To the west, Kasimi.” To the north, the Brahmanical Nañci Vihāra. These are the boundaries. Again, there are multiple problems with the reading and interpretation of this passage. I translate very tentatively, attempting to find coherence. See the apparatus to lines 16 to 18.
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
A donor of land rejoices in heaven for sixty millennia, while a seizer of granted land and a condoner of such seizure shall reside in hell for just as many.

The eastern border is Sorivāḍa. The southern border The western border is Nāgaruvu. The northern border
kavivelupu

The identity of the issuer of these plates is uncertain, and the text as printed by PS is not intelligible with regard to this. According to the ARIE report, the plates were issued by a Maṅgi, son of Indra Bhaṭṭāraka, but the report makes no issue of the fact that no such ruler is known, and treats another set of plates, issued by Maṅgi son of Viṣṇuvardhana and grandson of Indra Bhaṭṭāraka as belonging to the same king. According to Padmanabha Sastry’s discussion, the issuer is the King Bhaṭṭāraka Maṅgi mahārāja, the son of Pr̥thivīvallabha (… pr̥thivīvallabha nāmadheyasya putriṇa bhaṭṭāraka Maṅgirājan…). However, the preamble of the grant very definitely leads up to Viṣṇuvardhana II, introducing him as the grandson of Viṣṇuvardhana (I) and son of Indra Bhaṭṭāraka, then introducing him in line 8 as Viṣṇuvardhana (II) with a long list of ornamental epithets, all in the nominative. Further on, in line 11, PS prints literally, upadeśa-labdhena vijñap itḥ-eva-m ājñāpayati. This must surely mean that Viṣṇuvardhana II (introduced above in the nominative) commands as follows, having been petitioned ( vijñapitaḥ) by someone who in turn heeded ( labdhena) the religious instruction of Kanakanandi (introduced in lines 10 and 11) to do so. The problematic Maṅgi is introduced in between the two points, in lines 8 and 9. The words are printed by PS literally as follows: [mu]dinī grāmau . . vī lokasya pr̥thivī-vallabha nāmadheyasya putriṇo(tro) Bhaṭṭāraka Maṅgirājaḥ. If we reject the emendation of putriṇo (cited in his discussion as putriṇa) into putro, and instead read it as (or emend it to) putreṇa, then we have an instrumental here, to be picked up by labdhena in line 11. The only problem with this is the apparent nominative maṅgirājaḥ, which must then be emended to maṅgirājena (or an instrumental ending might be found in the unintelligible syllables read after this by PS).

Thus, the grant was probably made by Viṣṇuvardhana II, on the instance of Maṅgi. The latter was probably a subordinate, perhaps related to the royal Cālukya line, or he and his father may have borne names shared with that line out of affectation. It is also possible that he is Viṣṇuvardhana II’s son, later known as Maṅgi Yuvarāja. But the title bhaṭṭāraka does not seem appropriate for a prince, and the manner of his introduction implies that he was the son of some other pr̥thivī-vallabha than Viṣṇuvardhana II.

The seal legend viṣamasiddhi also speaks against identifying the issuer as Maṅgi Yuvarāja, and there is a final piece of independent, though circumstantial, evidence for assigning this charter to Viṣṇuvardhana II. The Peddāpurappāḍu plates (set 1) of Viṣṇuvardhana II, discovered together with the present plates, record a grant to presumably the very same ācārya Kanakanandi, and are dated (probably) in the first year of Viṣṇuvardhana II. Dating the present plates to the second year of Maṅgi Yuvarāja would separate the two grants in time (albeit only by about ten years), whereas dating them to the second year of Viṣṇuvardhana II would put them very close to one another.

B ), without facsimiles and without translation. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on the published edition. However, this edition contains such an inordinate number of typographic (or other) mistakes, that duplicating it to the letter would serve no purpose, and in some cases the intent of the editors cannot be reconstructed. My edition therefore shows my conjectures of what the actual reading of the plates may be and how that should in my opinion be emended. Every locus where my "reading" of the assumed original diverges from the printed edition is marked up as unclear and tentatively in my edition, whereas loci marked as unclear by the original editors are shown here as unclear, but confidently read. My apparatus cites the printed edition where I deviate from it in a major way or where my conjecture is uncertain, but I silently correct some obvious typos, ignore some nonsensical emendations, and apply my own segmentation.
